Cpp - Compilation flags

Created:2018-02-11  Last modified:2018-02-11

  • Introduction
  • Compilation
  • Linker
  • References

  1. Introduction

    Compilation flags are the argument of g++ compiler. Adding different flags would result in diffferent compiled files.

  2. Compilation

    flag in compilation process (from .cc to .o)

    1. -std=c++14

      Using c++ 14 standard

    2. -g

      enable gdb

    3. -Wall

      print warning

    4. -Wextra [or -W]

      This enables some extra warning flags that are not enabled by -Wall.

    5. Warnings that are not enabled by Wall and Wextra

      1. -Wfloat-equal: Warn if floating-point values are used in equality comparisons.
      2. ...

    6. -Werror

      switch all warnings to error, this will stop compiling.

  3. Linker

    flag used in linking process.

    1. -Ldir

      tell the linker the location of the libxxx.a or libxxx.so file

      e.g. -L/home/nan/Documents/3081/MinGfx/install/lib/MinGfx-1.0

    2. -lxxx

      tell the linker to link the libxxx.so or libxxx.a

      e.g. -lGL # the number of GL lib is libGL.a, a naming convention

    3. -Wl, option

      Pass option as an option to the linker. If option contains commas, it is split into multiple options at the commas. You can use this syntax to pass an argument to the option. For example, -Wl,-Map,output.map passes -Map output.map to the linker. When using the GNU linker, you can also get the same effect with -Wl,-Map=output.map.

      -Wl, rpath, dir # tells the linker that the shared library .so is located in the dir. So the process can find the shared library.
